src:
Irački premijer pozvao demonstrante da omoguće vraćanje života u normalu

03 Nov 2019, 19:35

































Irački premijer Adel Abdul-Mahdi pozvao je danas učesnike antivladinih protesta da deblokiraju puteve, ocenivši da je vreme da se život vrati u normalu posle mesec dana masovnih demonstracija na kojima se zahtevaju političke promene.Abdul-Mahdi je pozvao na otvaranje prodavnica, fabrika, škola i fakulteta, posle više dana uzastopnih protesta u Bagdadu i na većinski šiitskom jugu zemlje.On je u izjavi naveo da su ugroženost naftnih postrojenja i blokade puteva koštale zemlju milijarde dolara i doprinele rastu cena koji je sve pogodio.Desetine hiljada demonstranata okupljale su se prethodnih dana na bagdadskom trgu Tahrir i širom južnog Iraka, zahtevajući reformu političkog sistema uspostavljenog posle invazije na Irak 2003. godine, koju su predvodile SAD.Hiljade učenika pobegle su sa časova da bi išle na proteste na kojima se politička elita okrivljuje za raširenu korupciju, visoku nezaposlenost i loš kvalitet javnih službi.Demonstranti su danas blokirali puteve oko trga Tahrir zapaljenim gumama i bodljikavom žicom, a na jednoj od blokada razvili su transparent s natpisom "Putevi zatvoreni po naredjenju naroda". Deluje da su taktiku pozajmili od libanskih demonstranata, gde slični antivladini protesti traju od 17. oktobra, uz blokadu glavnih puteva u cilju povećanja pritiska na vlast.U dva talasa protesta u oktobru poginulo je najmanje 26 ljudi pošto su bezbednosne snage Iraka, uz suzavac i gumene metke, koristile i bojevu municiju protiv demonstranata.Otkako su 25. oktobra protesti nastavljeni posle kraćeg prekida, izmedju demonstranata i bezbednosnih snaga traju gotovo neprestani sukobi na dva mosta koja vode do takozvane Zelene zone, dela Bagdada u kojem se nalaze zgrade vlade i više ambasada.
text:
Iraqi prime minister calls on protesters to allow life back to normal

03 Nov 2019, 18:35

































Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul-Mahdi called on anti-government protesters today to unblock the roads, saying it was time to return to normal after a month of massive demonstrations calling for political change.Abdul-Mahdi called for shops, factories, schools to be opened and faculty, after days of successive protests in Baghdad and in the majority Shiite south of the country.He said in a statement that the vulnerability of oil facilities and roadblocks have cost the country billions of dollars and contributed to rising prices that hit it all. Tens of thousands of protesters gathered in the past days in Baghdad's Tahrir Square and throughout southern Iraq, demanding a US-led reform of a post-invasion Iraqi system in 2003. Thousands of students fled the classroom to protest high political elites blamed for widespread corruption unemployment and poor quality of public services. Demonstrators have blocked roads today about Tahrir Square with burning tires and barbed wire, and at one of the blockades they developed a banner with the words "Roads closed at the behest of the people." The tactic appears to have been borrowed from Lebanese protesters, where similar anti-government protests have been ongoing since October 17, blocking major roads to increase pressure on power.In two waves of protests in October, at least 26 people were killed as Iraqi security forces, with tear gas and rubber bullets also used combat ammunition against demonstrators.At the protests resumed after a brief hiatus on October 25, protests have continued between the protesters and security forces on almost two bridges leading to the so-called Green Zone, a part of Baghdad housing government buildings and more. the embassy.
